Posts.Content: I suspect it was a little bit harder for him. He is the one that needs support. If he is willing to share some details concerning his Dx, there are many here at this site that are willing to provide good information to assist him with his treatments decisions. In the mean time, the family should not panic. Encourage him to seek out an experienced medical team to start him down the road to recovery.
Posts.Title: just recently found out that my father has prostate cancer

Posts.Content: I would be very interested where you came across this information. Originally Posted by FeatherBoy Hi Harding, . In other words, the ADT will almost always lower your PSA to zero by itself even in the presence of metastatic disease. Radiation will not. Dave
Posts.Title: What should PSA be 5 months after castration?

Posts.Content: While you are waiting on the results of the biopsy, I would start looking for the best Oncologist you can find for his PC treatment. If scans are showing swollen nodes through out the body, then he needs a chemo treatment plan as soon as possilble. I'm not saying this to scare you, but this is a serious situation that needs immediate attention. I speak with some knowledge. My wife just went thru this process with her lung cancer.

Posts.Content: Steve Have your Dad or Mother always ask for a copy of all of the test results that has already been taken plus those in the future. Your Dad should start building his personal medical file with those copies so all the information will be available for review by other Doctors if needed. They should also ask for a CD or copy of all scans. They are usually available upon request.

Posts.Title: chemo for prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH From what I can see of your pathology report, you should consider yourself cured. Chuck Unless I can walk on water, I would never tell a PC victim they were cured. Any doctor worth his salt wouldn't do it either. I might call them a survivor, however, with certain obligations to tend to in the future. That being continued testing at intervals dictated by the PSA levels. This individual may not experience any problems for years down the road, however, one must never totally turn ones back on the possibility that it may return as a met somewhere in the body. I wish this individual well and congratulate him on his current success and look forward to further reports from him on his journey.

Posts.Title: Brand New

Posts.Content: Warning ! I had the exact same thing in the same spot. I procrastinated and one night after a bodacious supper it protrude through my stomach muscles (I've forgotten all the terminologies) and I ended up in the emergency room the next morning with pain like I've never experienced before or since. The doctor on call pushed it back through and I was at the surgeon's office the next day and had it repaired within 24 hours. If you could experience that pain for seconds....you would have already had it repaired. It was rough. edited to ad: I was about a year out from surgery

Posts.Content: I had minor incontinence after surgery, it gradually got better, even thru the radiation treatments and shortly after radiation, (about a week) I was completely dry.
Posts.Title: How soon after RP would aduvant radiotherapy start?

Posts.Content: I had minor incontinence after surgery, it gradually got better, even thru the radiation treatments and shortly after radiation, (about a week) I was completely dry.
Posts.Title: How soon after RP would aduvant radiotherapy start?

Posts.Content: There are a lot of us out here that have had similiar PSA's and GS scores. We have also had open surgery and more recently most have chosen robotic. His PC may be serious, but keep in mind there are options available post surgery. HT and/or HT/Radiation. Some of us believe in de-bulking and just getting it out of there. Surgery also permits the option of removing a number of lymph nodes to see if it has in fact spread to that system. Radiation alone will not provide that option. Second opinions are incouraged, no matter what options are considered. Good luck to you from one who has been there and done that.
Posts.Title: Newby wife

Posts.Title: Newby wife

Posts.Content: fivecents Congratulations and I wish you continued success in the future. Speaking of the future, I cring when I hear the word cured. There is no test or doctor on this earth that can make that prouncement. I cring because I have seen with my own eyes men that were told they were cured and less than 5 years later they found that uncontrollable PC had returned. How did that happen? It was because they had become convinced they were cured and disregarded any future testing. The PC had come out of remission, metastasizied to bone and other organs without detection. As a result treating required massive radiation and/or chemo to try to arrest the PC. You have started a journey down a road that appears headed for a long life, however, do not forget, it still requires CONTINUED PSA TESTING, never less than every 6 months. Good luck to you and your family........

Posts.Content: I had no symptons and had my first test at 68. My sig shows the results. D**n poor choices on my part.

Posts.Title: Medical Cannabis? Worth a try, I understand it can be helpful.

Posts.Content: My next question would be what kind of pain is he having? Bone, muscle, joint, or abdominal?
Posts.Title: Chemo working?

Posts.Content: My wife's infusions never resulted with any pains until they stopped giving her 2 of the 3 types she was being treated with. Within 2 weeks she started suffering from extreme total body muscle/skeletal pains. They started pain management with low doses of Lowertab and Oxycontin. That helped some but she didn't want to increase the dosages to higher levels. The Doc gave her a sample of a new drug called Cymbalta. Within 3 days her body pain is almost gone. She also started taking OTC NSAID's (Advil) so we aren't shure which one helped the most. Anyway between the 4 of them something is working better. Speaking as an experienced Lupron user (or victim, whichever) your husband can expect a number of SE's. Getting tired easily, hot flashes, muscle atrophy, bone loss, and others, but it also serves a purpose of reducing the size of the prostate, plus stops the body from producing testosterone which is a type of fuel for the growth of PC cells. Because your husband is already suffering, I pray the SE's are minimal Surely your doctor can establish some type of pain management while the chemo is working. Unless one is directly exposed to the horror's of chemo, most do not have a clue about its effects. Our prayers go out to you both....
Posts.Title: Chemo working?

Posts.Content: What is the name of the chemo your husband is being treated with?
Posts.Title: Chemo working?

Posts.Content: Eating healthy food is a good thing for the body, but it will not cure cancer. I would never try to treat my PC with someones special diet, just because of some result for some unknown person, that appeared to work (?) according to something on the internet. He should seek the services of an Oncologist that specializes in Prostate Cancer. Treatment of biochemical recurrence should have started long before his PSA rose to it's current level of 58. It may be a very difficult process (but not impossible) to bring it back to UDT. I wish him the best..............
Posts.Title: Has anyone tried the Plant Programme diet?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind ..Traditional Chemo has not proven to be very effective against PC, especially when you consider it's side-effects. At age 79, side-effects can be just as fatal as the cancer. .. Fariwind I have been reading your comments for while and have always thought you provided decent info, especially to the "newbys". The above quote is completely off the wall and not what someone without any knowledge of the ins and outs of PC should hear. A blunt statement without any supporting documatation is a little harsh. Maybe you were in a bad frame of mind when you wrote it. We all have been there and done that many times. I'm not jumping your case, I just reminding you that there are readers out there that do not have your knowledge and experience. Many of us are facing Chemo and with the help of an Oncologist that specializes in PC, we expect to live the rest of our lives as comfortably as possible.
Posts.Title: Casodex???

Posts.Content: Find a GOOD Oncologist that has a handle on treating cancers with chemo. My wife started chemo for lung cancer 5 months ago. Progress is being made but it doesn't happen over night. Our doctor is very positive about putting it in remission. If your doctor can only give you a death sentance 3 - 9 months out, he has already given up and will not fight for you. There are new medications being used every day, find a doctor that cares about YOU and will do everything possible to help you. You life is worth fighting for......................

Posts.Content: TKIGuy Here is a terrific web site that has over 800 stories of PC survivors. At this address you can choose your age group and find stories of others who have been down the road before you. http://www.yananow.org/query_stories.php#topoflist The whole idea is to spend as much time as you can, looking for valid information in sources such as Forums, books and professional medical sites, in order to be able to understand what the doctors are saying and being able to ask questions about concerns. Good luck and keep us posted on your progress.

Posts.Title: coping with celibacy

Posts.Content: lizm1616 In the US, a spouse must have Power of Attorney for Health Care and anyone else, related or not, must be listed on a HPPA agreement, signed by the patient, in order to receive any information. Everyone should review their legal files to make sure that in the event of an emergency, the family has options. Without legal protection, and if the patient is non-responsive, the family will not have any control of the treatments.

Posts.Title: Lupron

Posts.Content: There can be NO earthly reason for a (?) doctor to Rx Lupron to a 96 year old man with failing health, other than to take the $$$$$$$ out of your pocket and put in his. Having been there and done that with the SE's, and it was my father, I would never go back to that criminal again. Yes, criminal, which is the kindest compliment I can offer without using profanity. Please get another opinion from someone who would show some respect to his patient. I'm sorry if my comments are upsetting to some readers, but how could one of our PC brothers be treated in this manner?
Posts.Title: Lupron

Posts.Content: This has been a good discussion, shared with over 300 viewers, and I hope the postings will be taken seriously by all of them. Many thanks to those who commented about my beautiful lady who was always concerned more about my test than she was of her own. Happy holidays to all...........
Posts.Title: The word "Cured"

Posts.Content: My concern are the patients, who are in their 40's - 60's, who were treated and told they were cured and never looked back. Later they find their PSA has sky-rocketed and they have mets that have appeared in bone, lymph nodes, and/or other organs. Now a more drastic treatment must be found (chemo) to try to halt its growth. Success (remission) has now been placed at a very low percentage rate. Why take those chances when one can monitor their PSA every 3, 6, or 12 months and be pro-active before it gets out of control?
Posts.Title: The word "Cured"

Posts.Content: This has been a good discussion, shared with over 300 viewers, and I hope the postings will be taken seriously by all of them. Many thanks to those who commented about my beautiful lady who was always concerned more about my test than she was of her own. Happy holidays to all...........
Posts.Title: The word "Cured"

Posts.Content: xux The doctor should have immediately retested. It would be nearly impossible for the PSA to increase that quickly in 3 months from a 1.4. Seeing the Urologist is the correct next step. Tell your Dad to relax. I'd bet big money on lab error. It has happened to me. I had about a 40 point jump on one of my test once and my Oncologist immediately retested. Errors happen once in a while, thats why one has to pay attention to what going on and not be led like a blind sheep. Like the old saying "Knowledge is power". Good luck with the Uro and keep us informed.

Posts.Title: coping with celibacy

Posts.Content: I know there has been much written about this word that has been passed from doctor to patient, and those with great knowledge (?) to newly treated cancer victims. I heard this word after my PC surgery. My wife heard this word from her surgeon 3 years ago after her lung surgery. After a year and a half of chemo, she lost her battle for life, 33 days ago. Mine is back but hasn't reached my self-imposed level of PSA to start treatments again. Point being, one should NEVER ignore the fact that one has had cancer. Unless he can walk on water, there is NO doctor (or anyone else) on this earth that can predict a future without a recurrence, at some point in time. It is possible that treatments may take it into remission for an extended period of time, but one must be forever vigilant and continue testing. Always remember this word, remission. It is something you can live with comfortably.

Posts.Title: The word "Cured"

Posts.Content: newporter Its a mystery to me. Nothing has changed with the diet or medication. My COPD medications has remained the same. No tea's or special juice. I basically live on coffee for liquids. Weight has never been a problem for me, I eat very little (1 meal a day) and love chocolate. I would never qualify to be a poster boy for healthy living. Just luck in the draw of the right genes I guess is why I'm still around. What ever is going on, I'm going to enjoy a little more time of my Lupron vacation.
Posts.Title: New & Wondering update 8-17-12

Posts.Content: Congratulations on your PSA levels. My Oncologist follows the protocol of noted Oncologist Dr. Stephen Strum, co-author of "A Primer on Prostate Cancer". During the treatment with ADT (Lupron in my case) if the PSA level remains at undetectable (<0.05) and the Testosterone level remains at <20 ng/dl for 12 months, then one can stop the ADT and enjoy a vacation from the treatment. PSA and T must be monitored regularly. They both go together. If you are not having the T level checked, then you don't know for sure if the ADT is working as well as it should. I was bordering on the edge of restarting another round of ADT, when for some unexplained reason my PSA started going back down and my T is normal for some one my age. My doctor said to continue whatever I was doing, something was working. Whatever it is, I'm a happy camper for now. Next check in 3 months.
Posts.Title: New & Wondering update 8-17-12

Posts.Content: Androgen Deprivation Therapy (ADT) is used to stop the production of testosterone which fuels PC cells. It is Rx'd for a period of time in order to hopefully knock the PC into remission. After PSA levels indicate its appropriate to stop ADT, the testosterone levels will return to near normal levels and the your general feeling of well being will return. Castration is forever. This is a very brief description of ADT. The are volumes written in detail in this Forum. Yes or No as what to do requires research then make a choice and live with the decision as best you can, for a long as you can.
Posts.Title: How bad is hormone treatment

Posts.Title: How bad is hormone treatment

Posts.Content: I will applaud any man's choices on how to deal with his PC. I try to provide information to those who ask questions based on my own experience. I also wish we could all have the perfect results predicted by our physicians, but it will never happen. Some fair better than others. Why? Thats outside my knowledge base. I offer my prayers to you and your family.

Posts.Content: You have nothing to worry about. Your PSA numbers are considered undetectable. These numbers 1 1/2 years after surgery are to be celebrated. RELAX .................
Posts.Title: Could nerve sparing be a reason for detectable psa after prostate surgery ?

Posts.Content: mkane09 I'm curious. With a history of GS 4+5, why did you wait 18 months between 7/10/06 (PSA <0.06) and 1/10/12 (PSA 13.90) for a PSA test? Were you being treated with something during this time? Its a pretty established fact that someone with a GS9 should be tested frequently, (usually every 3 months) in order to catch a post treatment failure at its earliest point. Are you on any type of treatment at this time?
